div.p: THE REMONSTRANCE OF THE KINGDOME OF ENGLAND, TO THE ƲNIVERSITJES OF OXFORD AND CAMBRIDGE.
With A Review of the COVENANT.
By way of Quaere.
• N SATISFACTION TO ALL those who desire thorow information of the Danger thereof.
Printed for the publique good. 1647.

div.head: THE REMONSTRANCE OF THE Kingdome of ENGLAND to the Vniversities of OXFORD and CAMERIDGE, Concerning the late Covenant, which is now pressing upon the Kingdome.
div.p: THat the Eyes of the whole land are now fixed upon you, to behold your demeanour in this action, which therefore is like to prove the forge, wherein you shall worke out to your selves either a lasting fame, or infamy; that the example of your constancy in the deniall of this Covenant will throughly confirme both the consciences and outrages of those weake ones, who are almost yeilding to the threats and pretences of reason, wherewith this Oath is to be urged.

That the subtile enemy doth already take advantage of your silence, to noise abroad your willingnesse to take this Oath when it shall be tendred: so that many deluded ones amongst us have subscribed to the rumour of your example: and those of us who out of a well- • rounded Conscience have refused it, do suffer under the guilt of obstinate and ignorant malignants, since we dare deny that, which, is said, a whole University doth assent unto.

And therefore, as you will answer before GOD the losse of those weake soules, who by the aforesaid false rumour may be seduced, & as you will answer before His Majesty (whom we doubt not but God will once againe set in the Throne of his Fathers) the losse of our Estates and liberties, which is certaine, if we shall deny this Oath, when it may be said that you received it; we conjure you, that you will, (both t • confirme our Consciences, and also to take off from us (& •• om every single man of your selves too) the envy and danger
of particular refusals) make a timely and generall Declaration of your unanimous dissent from the taking of this oath, so derogatory to the Honour of God, so destructive to the peace of the Church, and so prejudiciall, in the Consequence, to His Majesties Just Rights and Power: And we shall ever pray for your flourishing estate.

p.hi: You are farther requested, that this our Remonstrance be read in your Chappels, and (so far as without danger it may) be imparted to the rest of the Ʋniversity.

div.p: To the Right Worshipfull the Reverend Deane of Christ-Church these present.

div.head: A WARNING For all the COUNTIES of ENGLAND To awake speedily out of their dreames, and apply themselves to all just meanes for the recoverie and preservation of their Liberties, because of a present designe to expell the most faithfull out of their House of Commons, and to frustrate all the Countries good Elections, that so the Malignant party may bring the free Commons of England now (after all their bloudy sufferings) into cruel Thraldome, and make themselves Lords over them.

q.p: Run to and thorough the streets in Jerusalem, [as it may be truly said of Westminster and London] and see now, and know, and seeke in the broad places thereof, if ye can finde a man, if there be any that executeth judgment, that seeketh the truth, and I will pardon it.
And though they sweare the Lord liveth, surely they sweare falsly.
They have spoken words, swearing falsly, in making a Covenant.

div.p: WEE the free Commoners of England, have been (for the generall part) like Merchant-Adventurers, who according to the Poet, Per varios casus, per tot discrimina rerum, &c. through many great difficulties and dangers do saile into far Countries, with great costs and charges to fetch home rich Treasures, the which when they have gotten, they do return ther with joyfully: and yet upon their own Coasts, or in the very harbour at home, through the negligence, or ambition, pride, covetousnesse, falshood, or contention of the Ship-Master, or his Mariners, do suffer wrack, and lose the fruit of all their costs, Adventures, and travels.

Have not we done the like to fetch home those invaluable treasures of Liberty and Justice, which were carryed so far remote (as almost past recovery) by these two notorious State-Robbers, boundlesse-Prerogative and predominant Tyrannie; and yet now after all our expence of men, time, trade, and monies, with innumerable difficulties, & dangers over past we are thro • gh the pride, ambition, covetousnesse, treachery, and contention of our Ship-Masters, and their Ministers (unl • sse wee our selv • s • he free Commons of England, do timeously stand up and lay hold upon the tackling) like to perish utterly and lose the pretious Treasures for which we have adventured so far, and paid so deare.

For now though the war be ended, and that there are none in armes to abridg us of our liberties, or to turn back the s •• ord of Justice, & that according to the Protestation Vow; Covenant, & manifold D • clarations, we look for judgment, but behold more abundan • oppressio • ; for righteousness • , but behold a more hiddeous cry, a c • y of millions of Widdowes, fatherlesse, and friendless • , of maymed, and dismembred, of plundered, sequestred, and destroyed, of unjustl • imprisoned, and oppressed, of despis • d persecuted, and hated, for truth and conscience sake, of defrauded, and deceived, of des • rving men; and Souldiers sleighted, rejected, and unpaid, cum multis, aliis quos jam prescribere longum est; and the eares that should heare are deafe, and the eyes that should pitty are blinde, verifying the old Proverb; who are more blind then they that will not see?

And are not certain men of Beliall, whom we have unhappily chosen and intrusted to man, and mannage forth this great Bark of our State, for the regaining of those rich Treasures (for which wee have expended so much pretious bloud, and so much inestimable wealth) now studying and endeavouring after so many stormes and tempests, rockes and sands escaped, to deprive us of all the fruit and benefit of our Adventur • ? And among many of their treacherous devices, this which I shall here discover is not the least, or most inconsiderable, to wit.

To enforce the taking of (the Scotch hooke, I meane) the Covenant, upon all the Members of the House of Commons, without resp • ct to tender consciences, and in case of refusall, to suspend or expel, as if the Covenant were essentiall, or that without i • , a man could not bee capable to serve his Country in the Parliament, using it no o • herwayes, then as an index ex • urgatorious, to expunge out of the House the most uprig • t & conscien • ious, serviceable, & faithfull to their countries, contrary to the first end or enjoyning it, which was to discover the malignant party, & not to drive away the approved and faithful; but so they do, tha • o • hey may pack to themselves (as Chea • es do Cards) a set of Memb • rs for their own Game; the which subtil and serpentine course, so little seen or notifyed
abroad, will certainly) wi • hout pr • vention) ruine us utterly; For they doe but bind themselves by oathes to work wickednesse, and as the Psalmist saith, Psalm. 49. frame mischiefe for a Law. And we may most justly cry, A consederacy, a confederacy, a Plot, a Plot, a Plot co • sisting of a threefold not and therefore not easily broken) of Prerogative Lords, Pretbyterian Commons, and Mal • gnant Citizens. But here is comfort, The Lord shall bee our Sanctuary, Esa. 8.14. and he w ll diappoint their devices, so that they shall not be able to accomplish their enterprize, for their councels shall be carried head-long. Iob. 5.13, 14.

p.hi: Awake, awake, therefore O ye free Commons of England, and let not your servants ride, while ye your selves are by them tran pled under foot. Can the • e be a g • eater presumption, or a more intollerable abuse then this, to trample upon your native rights and immunities in such a contemptuous sort before your faces? for what availeth the free-men of England, to have the power of electing their own M • mbers for Parliaments, if a few presumptuous person (their fellowes, yea their servants (more subtill (though not more honest) then the rest may by any strange new found Engine, expel and extrude their Trustees the Commons House, without any just cause: this is to l • t the people ch ose, & then they will cull, and this they are now about, if they can attain unto it.

div.p: If it bee not a plot, to drive the most faithfull and serviceable for the Countries 〈◊〉 , why is the Covenant now in the time of no hostility, and of lesse cause of jealousie, more zealously and violently pressed & imposed in the House of Commons, then ever it was in the worst and most perillous times, there is now (blessed be God) no such cause amongst them (as was then) of distrusts and feares, unlesse it be by treacherous and Lordlike spirits, least they should be detected and anticipated in their treasonable & treacherous designes, and disappointed of their imperiours rule, & domineering power over their fellow Commoners, & why must those persons, whose fidelity hath been sufficiently approved in the sight of the whole world, be now suspended and expelled, if they shall refuse the taking of this make-bate Covenant, although they have alwayes refused it & would never take it, in the time of greatest diffidence, extremity, & doubt, & yet were then never suspected, or in the least, therefore opposed or interrupted, nor is there any such strictnesse used for Malignants, and D linquents, and our profess • d Adversaries to take it, many of them are & have bin dismissed without it; yet not a man now in the House must escape it, although his conscience scruple it, & his judgment doth not approve it, a Mysterie! a miserie!

The end (if I mistake not) of the Peoples assembling of a Parliament, is principally, and primarily, to receive their Petitions, to heare
hear their complaints, and to redresse their grievances, to secure the good and wholsome Lawes, to abolish the bad and impertinent, and instead thereof to provide and make new for the peoples further and future welfare, to execute justice and judgment, to deliver the unjustly imprisoned, and to relieve the oppressed, and not to spend their daies and studies upon questions fruitless and unprofitable for the Common-wealth, in devising and prescribing to themselves (like some lawlesse Lords of Mannors) boundlesse priviledges, which differ in nothing from exorbitant Prerogatives, in forging and framing of Oathes and Covenants (which savour more of policy then piety) for gins and snare • , in making parties, and disputing of particular interests, in exhausting the people of great sums, and when they are gathered, in disposing of them among themselves.

But these men, now having by the new modell of an Independent Army (as they and their gracious creatures are pleased to terme it, unto which under God they doe owe their lives and beings, yea, and their best endeavours, for the safety they now enjoy, who before, for fear, sate (as I may say) like a company of wild fowle, upon the watch and the wing, expecting daily when to fly) subdued their so much feared adversary, are labouring strenuously to make a new modelled Parliament out of the old mold, that so they may advance their own power to pull downe their first and best Assistants; destroy the Liberty of the people, and establish that by Law for their owne advantage, whereunto (they know) those faithful ones wil not concur nor consent, and the which they could never have had the opportunity to have done, had they not been beholding unto them for the use of their sword. O honourable reward! O rare gratitude!

Happily it will be said, I am too bold: I believe indeed, I am more bold then welcome, but it matters not, for my boldnesse is only conversant about that which concerns me, and all the Freemen of England: Truth suffers too much by simple silence: let them be quiet slaves that love to be so, I do not, & if this ill kind of men wil not hear of their own evil doings let them do none, if they desire not to be reproved, let them do nothing that is reprovable, and then they may with confidence look up. None but a gauled horse will kick when he is troubled; nay, oftentimes before he is touched: and that Master truly deserves to be deceived and abused by his servants, that knowes and sees they deceive and abuse him, and will neither reprove nor question them.

The power is ours and not theirs, and we lent it not them to destroy us; I am confident the meanest Rustick in the Kingdom, did not intend it, nor can any such men think, that plaine Clubs and clouted shooes will be so contented: the people are not so stupid, but do expect a more exact accompt
and ample satisfaction, then they have yet had, for their profuse expence of wealth and blood, yea and better fruits then they have yet received after full six years session, or els assuredly they will never be pleased nor appeased. And it is dangerous raising the great waters, for they are not so easily allayed.

The City petitioned with their former Remonstrance, that not an honest man in the Kingdome, who was not of their judgement, (for such was the expression in effect) might have any place of trust or office in the Common-wealth. And doth not this present practice of some certain men in the House of Commons, intend as much both in Parliament, and Kingdome? for none shall be accounted worthy (by their good will) to sit among them unlesse he take the Covenant, be of their mind, sing their note, and subject their judgements to their crooked wills, and their persons to their illegall, irregular Ordinances and Orders. O just Powers! O pure priviledges!

Yeeld this, and yeeld all: lay downe the Bucklers here, and give them the field. Why do we therefore sit musing? let us up and be doing, for if now, we will neither heare nor see, we shall suddenly feele, ond that to our sorrow and shame, why then doe we sit still, untill our Liberties be betrayed, and wee and our posterities inslaved? Let us therefore demand a reason of this, and of all other their illegall and unjust practices and proceedings, and let us see and know what matter of fact or just cause of exception, they have to charge upon any, who are justly chosen, before they do suspend or exclude them from their Councels and Assembly. And if they doe refuse to do us justice, maintaine our Liberties, and to yeeld us redresse according to our distresses, and the duty of their places, let u • declaime against them, and disclaime them, remonstrate, and renounce all their Ordinances and Orders, doe as the London Butchers have done, and yeeld them no more obedience, assistance or contribution. For why should we stand still, to be bound in our own garters? observe and preserve them, to be inthrauled by our own power?

And for the more manifestation, that it is a plot, and practice, by the vile of the House and their confederates, against the faithful of the House & their friends, by those that would sell, and betray us and our Liberties, & deliver us up for slaves, to serve their owne unrighteous ends, against those that would preserve us and our Liberties, and faithfully discharge their trust and duty to their Countreys, I will here by the way, propound a few Quaeries.

1. Whether the taking of the Scotch 400000.l. Covenant bee essentiall to an English Parliament? If not: Why then must not hee be
thought fit to sit in this Parliament, that taketh it not, there being no other just exception agai • st him?

2. Whether it be no • contrary to the Law of GOD, and of this Nation to ob • rude an Oath upon any man contrary to his conscience? if yea. Why then doe they who are chosen to preserve the known Lawes, and the Peoples immunities, and that have volun • arily sworne therunto, impose Oathes and Covenants wi • h violence, and those new and strange ones, • ubious, and mysterious upon the Freemen of England, especially on their own Members? and are not these thus first in perjury themselves?

3. Whether this practice be not in its own nature, and intent answerable to that point of the Cities former Petition and Remonstrance, wherein they pray that none disaffected to the Presbyterian Government &c. may be employed in any place of publike trust? If it bee, (as indeed they are as like, as ever were two twins, yea, as if they were both spit out of one mouth) whether this designe not the same in its nature & end, with that of the Cities former Petition and Remonstrance, and of as (if not a more) dangerous consequence?

4. Whether it be not direc • ly against the native rights and immunities of all the free born of this Nation, to suspend and expell, without just cause, by a new devised Engin of their own, any Member of Parliament justly and freely chosen by the people, and by them intrusted and sent to Negotiate for their welfare in publlke?

5. And lastly, notwithstanding all their many (feigned) Fasts and Humiliation, Oathes, Vowes, Promises, Pretences and Protestations, what one just, or good deed, have these sort of men done, or suffered to be done for the Publique, since that Evening the King departed. Dic quaeso, & mihi eris alter Apollo. The People cry: None: and let them shew if they can.

The pooore oppressed prisoners for debt, have petitioned them above these five years, only for redresse according to Magna Charta, and there are at this instant above 300. copies thereof delivered to the Members of the House of Commons to that purpose, and yet cannot these perishing prisoners have their Petition either read, heard, or granted, nor receive any kind of redresse, but still lye and languish in their miseries under the hands of cruell creditors, and extorting Goalers, who use them more like villaines then Christians, or free-born men of England.

Were it to passe an Ordinance for the paying this, or that man among themselves, his arreares, who happily was never out one pennie, but hath rather repaired a broken estate, (as it is well known many of
them have) by the service of the State, they would presently order a day to di • patch and passe it.
A blessed Generation, and mighty and the hopes, which this long diseased, and distempered Nation ha • h, of recovering by them.
Now heare O heavens, and hearken O earth, and judge, all ye Na • ions of the ea • th, between the free Commons of England, and this their deare Parliament.
div.q: Vertamur in Syllam, Cupientes vitare Charibdem.
div.p: By seeking to avoid one Tyrant, we are likely to fall into the hands of many.

This sort of men, have already by this device, caused Major Harrison (a la • e chosen Member) to leave the H • use, and though an approved, godly man, occasioned him to go into Ireland, for otherwise, be cause his conscience could not admit of the Covenant, they would haue suspended or compelled, and others that stay, being unwilling to leave there places, will be so insnared, as that they can neither be free in there Councels, Speech, or Votes. And what then I pray is this Parliament? An English one, or a French? or not rather a Norman?

Wherefore, good Countrey-men; out, and looke about, for the threed is very fine spunn: the distinction is very subtill, and can hardly be discerned, it is as little in pronuncia • ion, (pre ence I mean • ) as between Sibboleth, and Shibb • leth, they have the voice of Iacob, but the hands of Esau: Howso v • r the Apostles rule is sure, ye shall k • ow them by • heir works: And if my sig • t faile no, there is one Stapleton (an Hoth mite) and one Hollis (a •
Edomite) that hav • a chief • hand in this plot: Long have they b en hammeri g of it, a d now t • ey have found a time and opertunity to act it, others I could name, their fellow confederates trai • ors to their Countrey, and enemies • o the fundamentall Lawes, and publick Liberties, Lambs they are in sh w, Foxes in Councel, and destructive in practice and action. Great Heads and Poli • icians men call them; w • o b • pretended R • ason, would make you beleeve that Rats-bane is as good for you as a Cordial; argue ye out of your Christian name, and can propou • d you a necessity for plain deceip • , and knavery. A company of cunning, crafty, deceitfull workers. Observe and consi • er them, y • d • too o • ten deliver your mindes and purposes into S •• kes bosom, • ow make ye bu • good use of this warning peece, and ye may happily before long, have a list of them, &
of their good actions, that so ye may see, what jugglers and Impostors yee have intrusted and imployed; and accordingly call them to an accompt, and provide for your selves a remedy against the like abuse, and treachery.

And now they have voted the disbanding of the Army, let us beware least they vote away all our Rights and Liberties, as in divers particulars they have begun, if we will but sit still and let them go on.

The Authors of this good worke, are the same, which doe so violently presse the Covenant, ye may (as I tell you, plainly know them if ye will but marke them) and I doubt not but the same Stapleton and Hollis can both name and number unto you the men, both principall and complices, long have they travelled both in heart and braine with this admirable designe, but could never untill now finde a season to bring it forth. They streigned to have had this Army disbanded, even while there was an Army of another Nation lodging within our bowels; but then it was so unseasonable, that even the weaker sort and such among them of more imperfect sight, (who like Children are led by the glow-worme light of anothers deceiptfull reason, or that like unto men, who having lost their way in the night, doe follow an Ignis fatuus for a true guide) were against it, and so then it could not be carried.

But the Scots are now no sooner gone, have sorce set up their horses at home, and loosened their Swords from their Loynes, but this inoffensive Army is to be disbanded, and why? are the people so well setled? are things so wel reformed and rectified, and are the people so fully satisfied? is not every man discontented, and distasting the unjust proceedings of the Parliament? I wish there were no cause for it: but who seeth not that there is more wickednesse and mischiefe wrought now by Authority, and more plots and devices daily framed and acted to spoile us of our Liberties, and rob us of our Lawes, (the bulwarke to secure every mans right) then ever was yet unto this day by open enemies.

There was no such haste or importunity to have Major Generall Massies Brigade dissolved, although multitudes of complaints came against it, and that there was of a long time no use of it: yet this must not stay, nor be demurred on? And I could wish that ye should in some degree, see the working of this Mystery.

The same men that have produced this work, did first contrive it, and may justly be suspected to deliver the plat-forme thereof to the City, who gave it forme, and cast it into a Petition and Remonstrance, and then presented it at an appointed time to the Parliament, having the
Lords sure and wholly, and assurance (yee may conceive) of countenance in the House of Commons, and note that the acceptance, which this their last Petition and Remonstrance found, was answerable to this present effect, and that the House hath ever since acted according to the heads of it, for hence, under pretence of satisfying the Citizens in their Petition, the Covenant must be urged, an Order made against, (edifying each other in the Gospell, teaching and interpreting the Scriptures, by any other, then Canonicals, (as if the gifts of the Spirit of God, were onely intailed upon a Black-coat, Hye for Bishops) that none should preach the Word of God, but such as had Ordination from the Pope, for such is that (by derivation) which they do mean and enjoyn; and now they have answered another point of the same Petition, to wit, in voting the disbanding of this Army. But is not the whole Kingdome as worthy of satisfaction, as the proud Malignant, illegall Mayor of London, and his like Brethren the Aldermen, and a few illegall Common-Councell-men?

There was a Petition presented the other week from the Counties of Hertford and Buckingham, for Justice and confirmation of liberty, and many other excellent benefits for the Publike, but that cannot be heard, nor have an answer, although they have been attended by some of the Counties ever since, yea some would have had it cast out of the House; such men doe most justly deserve to be themselves cast out as dirt, or as Salt which hath lost its savour: Shall we be prescribed by them what to Petition for? Must we present our grievances, as shall please them, or as we feel their pulse?

Ye see and hear now Countrey-men, and are by this like to feel of what spirit these men are, and what comfortable redresse you are like to have, if yee will be content with their courses: away with such men from the Earth.

These men are like Strafford and Canterbury, birds of the Lords feathers, (by their promotion or recommendation) and they look, if they can but make us slaves, that they might be all Lorded with their Lordships; but I had rather see the heads of all Traytors to the free-commonalty of England divided from their shoulders.

It was very requisite, and wisely done, that they should vote down this Army, because it is the onely block, and stumbling-stone to their designe of Presbytery and Lordly predominancy, and that it may not be a refuge pillar for the oppressed and distressed Commons of England whereon to leane, in claiming of justice, and of their just rights and liberties; down it must be, but no mention of reward for it, nor of raising moneyes to pay it;
but now they have done what they did require, what should they do with them but turn them out of doores: so having done with the rod, all that remains for them now, is, to devise how to cast it into the fire.

The next act, will be a re-establishing the King on his Throne, in case he shal but establish the many-headed monster of Presbytery, that so the Lords and the Lairds here (as the Scotch-man saith) that is, the chief man of every Town and Parish, may with the domineering Presbytery, rule the rost, and tyrannize over the common People here, their estates and liberties, as the good Lords and Lairds, with their Presbytery, do over the poor ignorant Lord-ridden People there. And here will be a confirmation of that pretended happy union between both Kingdoms. And thus both Nations will be both one, and alike equall in slavery and thraldome, that the one may not mock the other any longer.

Is there never a Roman spirit left, that dare interpose, and protest for his Countrey, against these destructive Councells, and Votes for Norman Bondage? I am confident it would be a gratefull act, and would not want owners: yet for my part, I take, not such their Votes for Decrees, like those of the Medes and Persians, unalterable; nor their illegall Ordinances for binding Lawes. And I hope I am not alone in this judgement; for we are not bound to obey to our own destruction: this principle, the safety of the people to be the soveraigne Law, is as true and as usefull for the people as for the Parliament. They are not chosen to make themselves our Lords, and us their slaves; but to free us from all exorbitant powers and oppressions, and to establish unto us our native Rights and Immunities, not to pretend the removall of a few old oppressors and oppressions, and to introduce many new ones in their stead, like the Tinker that mends one hole and makes two.

Now deare Countrimen, lay your hands upon your hearts, and if ye be willing after all, to become slaves to your fellowes and servants, sit still and be carelesse, and keep your selves warme by your fires, and take a pipe or two of Tobacco. But if ye be of my minde, and on my side, rouze up your spirits, and shake off this carelesse security; come, and boldly call your own servants to an account, and demand your own of them, with the advantage, know what improvement they have made for your good, of that talent of power and priviledge wherewith you have intrusted them, for the space of full six yeares, and do not at the last, like Issachars Asse, croutch down between two burdens; insupportable Presbytery, and intolerable Lordship. Let these men either forthwith redresse your grievances, and ratifie your native rights and liberties to you, according to their
Oaths, and end of their Election; or els remonstrate to the world, and renounce them, and restrain the power within its proper fountain.

The best end of the Staffe is yet in our own hand; if we have but hearts to make use of it to our best advantage, which is to preserve and secure our selves and posterity, lives, estates, and liberties, from irrevocable and inextricable vassallage and thraldome.

One caution note good Countrimen, and I have done, and will leave all to your consideration. May we not still feare, in case this Army be disbanded, (the which let us pray and endeavour to preserve, if we desire either safety or liberty) that unlesse we will condescend to the Scots (whose Commissioners lie here to negotiate) in things relative to the King and Church, for manner and forme, nay in every respect, that we shall be threatened againe with the Scotch blade. And who knoweth whether part of their late departed Army, may not (under the notion of opposing the Rebell Montrosse in the North of that Kingdome) be reserved in readinesse, to menace, or re-invade us, in case we come not up to their punctilioes?

I hope better, though I feare the worse; for who knoweth what a day may bring forth? It is good to foresee what may be, and to provide for the worst, although at present they do appeare like some clouds, which carrie storms, far removed, and not likely to fall upon our heads; yet cannot I discern our skie to be so cleare, as that we may discard all feare: True it is, that the clouds are somwhat broken and disperst, but do ye know how soon the wind may turn North, and bring together again, to the renewing the storm upon us? In my judgement the weather-cock of our State looks that way; and he is insensible, that feeleth not a Northern ayre in our Climate. And againe, have not the Malignants, and revenge-desiring Delinquents, an advantage when this Army is dissolved, to raise tumults and stirres, and by violence (as they have done heretofore) obtrude destructive Petitions, and inforce the Parliament to grant them, to the utter ruine both of Parliament and Kingdom? And what publike strength then is there to suppresse them? The Trained Bands of London: like to like, as the Devill said, when he danced with the Collier.

Nor will they only take away that faithfull, unparallel'd, well-govern'd Army, which hath (under God) preserved you, and so leave you and your liberties open to the destructive Acts and Councells of your adversaries; but will also appoint and set over you, in the others stead, an irreligious malignant Army of desperate wicked men (such as those of Major Generall Masseys late Brigade) to awe and curbe you, so that unlesse ye will
conforme to the indirect Directory, make your confession to the Priests; after the manner of the Papists, and professe the new-devised Confession of Faith, a long-studied Presbyterian Creed, such as our Fathers never knew nor believed, ye shall be plundered: Thus ye shall have a Religion established by the Sword, but not a Reformation according to the Word; the old Essexian-Designe: but he that took away the Head thereof (as with a whirle-wind) when his heart was full swolne with despight and pride, can as easily remove the instruments which are behind. In the mean time, it is well acted by Phil. the Jew, Jack and Wil. of Wales, and the West-Countrey Dennis. Gallant Lads: brave Cards and well packt, they do never deale, but there's a Knave in the stock.

And for the better ordering of this designe, the same party had determined among themselves, to have put out his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, as a man no longer worthy to be trusted, and to have put in (as I have heard) one Colonell Graves, one of the least in account for vertue and goodnesse, of all Sir Thomas his Commanders; a man indeed of no repute, either for piety or good practice; whose men were more like Gorings damning crew, then Parliament Souldiers: and usually like Commander, like Souldier.

But after a long debate in the House on Friday the fifth of March, as if they had never known Sir Thomas, nor had any experiment of his ability or fidelity, it was with great difficulty carried by a few more Votes, that he should command in chief over their new intended Army, yet they are resolved to choose him his Officers, as if he did not know now, as well as formerly, what men were fittest to be intrusted under him: and it must be disputed also, whether any but such as have taken the Covenant (the precious Covenant) shall be Commanders there or no, and why I pray, have not Sir Thomas his Commanders, who never took the Covenant, approved themselves more faithfull, and done the Kingdome more good service, then most ever did that took it? My opinion is, that man is more to be trusted, that refuseth the Covenant for conscience sake, then he that takes it (as the great Masters of the Assembly presse it) for policy and advantage sake. Oh but this is a true Touch-stone to discover him that is contrary to their minde and designe!

And although they missed of their purpose, in voting away Sir Thomas himselfe, they have voted away 8400 of his Foot, and foure Regiments of his horse for Ireland, a specious shew: But Anguis latet sub herba, why were not Massies Horse (which might better have been spared, and were much more fit for the temper of that corrupted Climate) sent thither?
Or why are they not now sought out and imployed that way? There are enough of them and such others very well at leisure, and would be glad of the service upon reasonable termes; you may heare of them at every Taverne and Alehouse, if not somtime in a worse place. Without doubt there might as many spare-Officers and Souldiers be gathered up about the two Cities, and the Garrisons dismantled and to be dismantled, and in other parts, as would make a sufficient Army for Ireland, without taking any from Sir Thomas: Col. Poyntz I believe could spare some, and all of them such as they may better trust, free-Covenanters, men of their own stamp and judgment: I conceive it no policy for them to trust any Independents in that desperate Kingdome, men whom they do so much distrust here at home, where comparatively there is no danger.

And why should this party intrust the same people in a Kingdome of greatest danger, and that in matters of highest nature, without swearing to the Covenant, whom they will not trust here at home, with a beggarly Headborough or petty Constables place without it? O admirable confidence! But this is a paradox, and I will unfold it.

Is it not to pack away this approved Army, which stands so much in the way, for Ireland, against the Rebells, as David did faithfull Ʋriah, to Rabbah, against the Ammonites, and then to raise one new out of the disbanded crew of desperate men, reserved and left behind to act their designe: for the Devill and his servants are best for those to make use of, that oppose the Kingdome of Jesus Christ. And well found out, grave Synod, pious Assembly; for such as are your principles, such are your meanes and Instruments. And saving your Reverence, what have ye done these foure yeares, plaid at cards, or onely studied where ye might have the best patterne of Church-government to serve your owne turne? Ye are but the Scots Apes; for ye have not studied a Religion for us out of Gods Word, but ye have borrowed us one out of Scotland, as wicked King Ahaz brought a patterne of the Altar from Damascus to Ierusalem: And now it is come to the taste, it doth not relish halfe so well as a Soland Goose; it goeth downe, ye see, but like chopt hay. Truly the Parliament might have sent for the copie themselves, and so have saved you a labour, and the Countrey all the charges of so long feeding such a company of Abbey-Lubbers. But to proceed, I hope this gallant Army, though it be thus voted, will not be thereby blasted. If the Parliament are this Nations servants, so are they. The Parliament were assembled, and solemnly vowed before God and all the world, to do judgement and justice, the which yet they never did, and to maintaine and
establish (the which I believe if they can choose, they never will) the rights and liberties of the Commons of England, and this Army hath fought and redeemed them, and, as I may say, brought them to the Parliaments hands to confirme and establish, the which the Parliament ought to do, and, as I conceive, this Army may justly chal • enge, and have just cause to see done; for they have equall interest with the Parliament in them, and have adventured much more for them: and as the one hath the word to vote, so hath the other the sword to act.

And therefore sure they will be so wise, for so it is expected, as not to undertake another Warre in a strange Kingdome, as desperate, and more dangerous then the former here, for these ingratefull mens pleasures, before they see the conditions performed to themselves, and fellow-Commons of England, in this their native Countrey; the which these men that have now voted them hence, have so frequently and so fearefully sworne and promised them before all the world (to wit) the establishing of the Lawes, and of the birthright and liberty of this Nation, the which this Army, under God, hath purchased by their sword, for themselves, their posterity, and for all the free-borne people of this Land; and if they see not these things done before they goe, if they go, let them be assured they shall never have them done after: and if they be not made good unto them in this their native countrey, let them never expect performance of them in another: No, if this party can but get this Army to bee a meanes for the pulling downe their enemies for them there, as they have been here; they hope by that time, few of this Army, or of their friends may survive, to exact any recompence, or fulfilling of Oaths and promises of them, but will leave that to them and their deare Brethren, the religious Scots, who never brake oath, to performe after their death; and so indeed this Covenanting party may happily fulfill one particular of their grand Solemne League and Covenant, in setling a uniformity in Religion (when there are none to hinder them) in the three Kingdomes.

So, it is better the Army should first see the fruits of their travails and perills past here, otherwise I conceive they have no cause, and as little encouragement to make new adventures for Trap-makers, and leave their native Countrey, their wives, children and friends, to the cruell mercies of their haters and persecuters. Let the covenanting party make use of such as they account their own, trusty blades, that will, like themselves, not onely swallow the Covenant, but the Kingdome too, if we will but stand still and let them doe what they will, or else let them begin againe and
presse: but I doubt they will not find such a simple parcell againe in both Kingdomes, as these poore despised, dispighted Independents, who came in willingly to their helpe, have borne the heat of the day, and have been (under God) their chiefe preservers, who have been more friendly and faithfull to them, then any of their Heathenish Covenanters, and yet now at last their reward for all, must be only a kick out of doors.

But seeing these devout Covenanters have so ill rewarded this Army and their friends who under God were their Guardians before they had either Army or Guard, I hope the Army will not be so unwise, but first to see their own Countrey, friends, and Families secured here in England, before they stirre one foot, or undertake for Ireland, Proximus quisque sibi, every man is nearest to himselfe, and as it hath been shewed, there are spare helps enough besides, let them therefore first send an Army of their owne Tribes thither, and see if they will doe as much for them there, as this same Army hath done here. Is it not better Countrey-men and friends, for this Army to stay at home and hold their Weapons in their hands, till they see their and our Birthrights, Priviledges, and Liberties, for which both they and we have sought and adventured our lives and estates, setled and secured here for themselves and us, their and our wives and families, posterities, and estates? and then if there be cause, and they willing, they may safely and with comfort goe and help their Neighbours: in the meane time, let them know, it is not wisdome for them to goe helpe to reale up another mans house, and leave their own to lie ruined and wasted, though charity be diffusive, yet it begins at home.

And although this Army hath both ploughed and sowed, and made way for a fruitfull crop, yet there be others (their and our enemies) that are ready, if this Army should either dissolve or depart, to enter into their harvest, and convert the whole advantage to their owne private uses, the Army hath fitted the wax, and if they once turne but their backs, this party Covenanters, will set to what seale they please, the which they think (like the Medes and Persians) cannot be altered, and it is more apparant, it will rather prove the image of the Beast, then the durable Statute of Truth. But forasmuch as they build on Sands, and dawbe with untempered mortar, there is no question but their Clay and Iron will never incorporate, nor cleave together, more then Nebuchadnezzars Image; and certainly such men cannot long prosper, more then Zimri did, that killed his Master.

These and such like corrupt and deceiptfull practices, (deare Countreymen) are the fruits of viperous Councels produced by traiterous spirits,
who for our Religion have already contracted with the Scots, as wicked King Ahas did with Tiglag Pileser concerning the Altar at Damascus: and now they endeavour by all indirect meanes to cheat and spoile us of our Birthrights, that so by our ruine and grinding the faces of the poor, they may raise to themselves a stock of predominancy and prerogative over us, as witness their illegall exercise, and daily practice of injustice.

Shall we alwaies be troubled with this Generation of Vipers, who like Janus, look two wayes, and carry two faces under one hood, that speake right faire to our faces, but devise mischiefe against us in their hearts, and vent them in their Councels, that love to be called Patrons, Patrons, but (if they be not prevented) will prove no better to us, then Morter-Peeces. They had better speak plaine English, and make an Ordinance in plaine termes for the expelling and persecuting of all honest and good men, abolishing all Law and Justice, the two preservators of liberty and propriety, as to do it thus in pharasaicall Characters, for they cannot draw a net so close, but a man may see through it, nor dig so deep to hide their wicked Councells, but the Alseeing eye of heaven will discover them. Thus, sweet Countrey-men, and free fellow-Commoners of England, have I in some part discovered unto you the secret working of this treacherous Mystery, the very substance of this plot, and the end of it. And now if ye love slavery, favour it, assist and promote it. Otherwise be warned. Rouse up your spirits, and secure your selves, and your Birth-rights, for which ye have spent so much blood, and paid so deare a price, oppose the proceedings, know a reason of these preposterous actions, vindicate your Power, and Priviledges, and cause those treacherous Machiavels, your false friends, and deceiptfull Servants to be brought forth and judged, that they may receive a reward according to their demerit.
All this considered (sweet Countrey-men) it is better for us to sing, O how happy were we in fore-seeing, then to cry when it is too late, had we wist.

And if ye be true Englishmen, and prize the liberties of your selves, and posterities, seeing the fetches and the falshoods of this ill kind of men, look in time to your selves, and to the weale of your native Countrey, and trust no longer to them, nor be any further deluded by them: Though they use never so much feigning and fleering, though they looke never so gravely and demurely, speak never so fairely, declare never so strongly, sweare never so devoutly, and fast never so frequently: yet I say in respect of the premisses do not trust them, nor wait any longer upon them;
But remember that our Country-man Adam After-wit, hath been too long my Lord Fore-Wits foole. Be taught therefore in time, before yee be taken; and let this I pray you prove a sufficient warning.

l.hi: Frote capillata, post est, occasio calva.

lg.l: Take time by the forehead, and loose no opportunity,
Free now or never. Slaves now and ever.

div.p: And lastly (my friends) note this, that those men who have now voted, that none but such as have or shall take the Covenant, and conf • rm to the Presbyterian-Government, shall be Commander in the new intended Army, nor have the Command of any Garison that is to be kept within this Kingdome, (a • beit the non Covenanters were the men that reduced them) will never (ye may be assured) in trust any with any place of Command or Power (after the work is done) in another Kingdom, that will not take the said Covenant, and subscribe to the said Antichristian-Government. And why then should they fight any more to gaine promotion and power for others, to rule over themselves? Surely this very particular should make all the well affected in the Land, to stand and seriously to consider what is intended against thē, and not be so forward to set one foot further for this ingrate, ill Generation. Do they not see plots daily laid to insnare them, and every pulpit full of raylings, & revilings, lyes, & clamours against them? do they not heare themselvs in writings, and Sermons, already censured & sentenc • d to persecution, even to imprisonment and dust? So that I am confident the Army and their Leaders should not long be in Ireland, before (to their great comforts and incouragement) they should heare some of their friends were executed, and multitudes of them imprisoned, in England.

But if his Excelency Sir Thomas Fairfaxes Commission, be made (as the Earl of Essexes was) viz For the preservation of the Law & Liberties of the Kingdom, and pro ection of his Majesties Subjects from violence and opression, then without controversy, it is his duty, and all theirs that are (in command) under him, and he and they have lawfull authority thereunto) to stand for the Law and Liberties of this Nation, and to defend the people from all tyranicall pressures and usurpations, for, for this very cause was he intrusted with the Sword: the which the Lord move his and their hearts seriously, now in season, to weigh and consider, for this is a day of trouble and rebuk, and of blasphemy: for
the child •• n are come to the birth, and there is no strength to bring forth. 2 Kings 19.8.

To pretermi what Mr. Byfield and Mr. Love formerly preached; what else but persecution did Mr. Vines in his Rabshaketh-like Sermon, mean at the mock-fast, for the suppression of heresies where there were none but (that which is most contrary to their Lord-like living) Independency principally spoken against, the which neither he, nor any tithmunging, antichristian Taskmaster of them all, can prove, or make forth by Gods word to be heresie, And if he will but truly interpret his then Text, 2 Pet. 1, 2, 3, he will find it doth more pa • pably reprove him, and such as he is, (then any other) who run before they be sent, come not in by the dores, but creep in at the windowes, teaching for doctrine the traditions and received opinions of men, a doctrin which consenteth not to the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrin which is according to godlinesse; but is after their own corruptions, denying the Lord Jesus that bought them, by with-holding his Kingdome and setting up themselves and their own Kingdom, above him; f • llowing their own pernitious and destructive waies and councels, by reason whereof every one even abhorreth the dayly sacrifice, as in Elies dayes, and through their insatiable covetousnesse, and intolera •• e pride, they will make marchandize of the people if they be not prevented: Hath not this man Vines and many others of his well fed fellowes 2 or 3. Benefices or such like things (and those no poore ones) a peece? And yet these gredy dogs are not satisfied, no, they would get into their possession the whole inheritance of the Lord. The which God of his mercy prohibit, for the Parliament assists in it, but no wonder; for so did the builders of old, reject the cheif corner stone, to the destruction of themselves and their Republick; but upon all the glory shall be a defence. Isa, 4.5.

Now to draw this warning to a full period, take this following summary of our present Calamities, and consider it seriously, consult, it advisedly, & accordingly act eff • ctually, for the timely prevention, and preservation of your selves, and your postereties, from insupportable bondage and thraldome.

BRethren and Fellow-Commons; God and the world knowes, that the well-affected party of this Kingdom, (discerned by their voluntary aid to the Parliament) having tryed all possible and faire meanes, as much as any people for number and power of any Kingdom or Nation ever did, by Prayers Assistance, Concurrence, Attendance, Petitions, Oblations Informations; and Discoveries, as well of Treasons, as of utter desolations, and perceiving themselves now at last to be in a farr worse condition, both in number and power (there Lives and Estates, yea and precious time also being so far spent) then they were at the first, and besides, like to loose all, and scarcely to have (or leave) so much as their Lives, Lawes, or Liberties for a prey.

And seeing, by manifold examples of grievous experience, that neither Petitions can be easily accepted, justice truly administred, the presses equally opened, the cryes of the poor heard, the teares of the oppressed considered, the sighes of the prisoners regarded the miseries of the Widdow and Fatherless pittied, nor scarcely any that are in distresse relieved but Lawes any way wrested, most of our freedoms restrained, Ordinances, protestations, Oathes and Covenants slighted, the hearts of all Estates, Kings, Parliament, priest and people obdur • d, the wicked for the most part absolved, the just oftentimes condemned and most of all in Authority perjured no •
onely by breaking that solemn Oath, which themselves did make and compelling others to take, but nevertheles, by persecuting those who make cōscience to keep it, even because they will not break it, In deep sad serious & lamentable consideration of all these grievous proceedings, and as much by feeling the smart, as hearing, seeing, or knowing the verity thereof, chiefly the oppressions, taxations, Insurrections, Rebellions, Persecutions, Violences, Robberies, Sequestrations, & Cumbustions, I with my poore one Talent, instead of him that hath Ten, out of a dutifull and consciencious love, tender and pittifull respect to my Nation now in this her great defection, and apparant dissolution, chiefly for the remnant thereof (who mourn in secret both for her great abominations sins dissolations, & their own particular transgressions, & who doutles are marked to escape the fury of Gods, fearfull indignation.)

Have used my best endeavours here both to shew the maladies and remedies of this sick swouning, bleeding, and dying Nation, that if God, hath not ordained it like Babel to sudden inevitable and utter destruction, it may yet be cured, and that (according to the Lords usual dealing, who in the midst of judgment remembreth mercy) a remnant may be reserved who in despight of Sathan, and all his Instruments may do justice & judgment, to the praise of his glory, So shall the Mountaines bring peace to the people, & the little Hils by righteousnes. Psal. 72.3.
